_header: Sweet Jesu now will I sing
Note: This is a combination of 2899 and 5075. The texts differ materially in arrangement and length in all MSS. Cf. 2876 and 5835; also promise of grace for saying this prayer, 6622
_description: A song of love to Jesus — in monorhyming quatrains

BodEngPoeta1.First Lines:
Swete Ihesu now wol I syngeTo þe a song of loue
                    longinge…
BodEngPoeta1.Last Lines:
…But pees & Ioye with gret lykyngeSwete Ihesu þerto
                    vs bringe. Amen.
BodEngPoeta1.Facsimiles:
Doyle,  I. A.,
                        ed.  
             The Vernon Manuscript. A Facsimile of Bodleian Library, Oxford, MS Eng.
                poet.a.1,
          with an introduction by A. I. Doyle. Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1987. 
Scase,  Wendy,  and  Nick Kennedy, eds.  
             A facsimile edition of the Vernon manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Eng. Poet. A. 1.
         Oxford: The Bodleian Library, 2011.
BodEngPoeta1.Editions:
Horstmann,  Carl,
                        ed.  
             Yorkshire Writers.
         2 vols. London, Sonnenschein; New York: Macmillan, 1895-96: 2.9-24.
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             The Minor Poems of the Vernon Manuscript, Part 2.
EETS
         o.s. 117 (1901; repr. 1973): 2.449-62.

OxfBal8.Transcription:
Ihesu crist My Soule boteIn myn hert þu sette a roteof
                    þy sone þat ys so souuteant grante þat þer yt greuwe
                    mote
OxfBal8.Note:
Stanza 4 only; added to blank flyleaf at end of volume by a hand of the
                    fifteenth century, followed by Latin couplet by same hand: Crimen mortale dum
                        desplicit est veniale / In nece quisque iacet dum ueniale
                    placet
OxfBal8.Editions:
Coxe,  Henry Octavius. 
             Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque
                oxoniensibus….
         Oxon: e Typographeo academico, 1852: 3.
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild. 
             A Register of Middle English Religious & Didactic Verse.
         2 vols. London: Oxford University Press for the Bibliographical
            Society: 1916-20: 1.131.
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Private Prayers in Middle English Verse.” 
             Studies in Philology
         36 (1939): 466-75: 470.

BLAdd22283.First Lines:
SWete Ihesu nou wol I syngeTo þe a song of loue
                    longinge…
BLAdd22283.Last Lines:
…But pes and Ioye with gret lykyngeSwete Ihesu þer to vs
                    bringe

BLAdd37787.First Lines:
Swete ihesu nou wul I syngTo þe a song of loue
                    longyng…
BLAdd37787.Last Lines:
…But þes & Ioye wiþ gret likyngSwete ihesu
                    þere to vs bryng. Amen
BLAdd37787.Editions:
Baugh,  Nita Scudder. 
             A Worcestershire Miscellany, compiled by John
                    Northwood, c. 1400, edited from British Museum MS. Add.
                37,787.
         Philadelphia, 1956: 129-42.

BLRoy17Bxvii.First Lines:
Swete Ihesu now wil I syngeTo þe a songe of luf
                    longynge…
BLRoy17Bxvii.Last Lines:
…but ioy & blis & ful likyngSwete Ihesu þer to vs
                    bryng
BLRoy17Bxvii.Note:
This version with 6622
                    preceding as prologue stanza. Last sixteen lines written by a different scribal
                    hand from preceding lines.
BLRoy17Bxvii.Editions:
Horstmann,  Carl,
                        ed.  
             Yorkshire Writers.
         2 vols. London, Sonnenschein; New York: Macmillan, 1895-96: 2.9-24.

Longleat29.First Lines:
Ihesu swet nowe wil I syngeTo the a songe of loue
                    langynge…
Longleat29.Last Lines:
…Bot pitte & ioy with gret lykyngeSwete ihesu þer to
                    vs bryngeAmen
Longleat29.Note:
100 quatrains with eight ‘Mary’ quatrains added in
                    margins
Longleat29.Editions:
Ogilvie-Thomson,  J. S.,
                        ed.  
             Richard Rolle: Prose and Verse.
EETS 293 o.s. 293 (1988): 50-63.

HunEL34B7.First Lines:
Jesu swete now wyll I syngTo þe a song of love
                    longyng…
HunEL34B7.Last Lines:
…Send it socowr and comfortyngþat it dreede noo wycked
                    thyng
HunEL34B7.Note:
31 quatrains. One prayer addressed to Jesus and two to Mary; portions
                    addressed to Mary begin ff. 84v (‘Mary lady moder bryght / thow
                    darst thow wylt thow artt of myght…’) and 85 (‘Mary þat
                    slakyst all woo / hell paynes kepe vs froo…’)
HunEL34B7.Editions:
Legg,  J. Wickham,
                        ed.  
             The Processional of the Nuns of Chester.
         Henry Bradshaw Society, 1899: 30-3.

TCD155.First Lines:
Ihesu swete now wole iche syngto þe a song of luf
                    longyng…
TCD155.Last Lines:
…but pees & myrþ wiþ gret lykyngswete Ihesi
                    þerto vs bryng
